After close to 4000hrs I've decided to leave a review.

The gameplay remains unchanged over the 7 years it's been around. There is the idea of don't mess with a good thing, but the gameplay and game modes haven't grown or evolved at all. The same thing you were doing 7 years ago is the same thing you're doing now and it's pretty stale. Psyonix has tried to add novelty game modes for limited time and thankfully they were limited because they have all been horribly designed and not fun at all. For years I've been wanting A HORSE like game mode for the training packs where you and a friend or friends can go into a training pack together and play HORSE while practicing the training pack shots. It's not much, but it would add a lot of value to the game because training packs are pretty boring by yourself for hours on end. But no, let's add a shitty football game mode to a soccer game with cars. Also, they've had the same exact rumble weapons for since the beginning. Why not add some new ones or change things up by having the weapons cycle each season or every hours or so like Apex Legends does with its map rotations so you have to change up your tactics? These aren't revolutionary ideas, but Psyonix would rather just sit back and do the bare minimum and pump their stale cash cow.

A couple years ago, the game transitioned into a battle pass monetization business model and the game has gotten decidedly worse for it. It used to have a thriving third party trading community, but Psyonix was greedy and wanted a piece of the pie. So they moved to the battle pass structure, changed the in game currency, and limited the in game items to be only purchasable with the new currency. This had three negative outcomes, 1: it completely killed the trading community, 2: they also over inflated the prices of everything so a lot of the cheaper items are now not worth it the effort to trade or the money to buy, and lastly 3: the only real way you can get items now is waiting for them to rotate into the extremely limited item store. The items in the item store rotate out but there's so many items and variations of them that you're going to be waiting a LONG LONG time for the specific item you were looking for, oh and btw if you buy and item in the shop it's not tradable with further added to the destruction of the trading community. Who the hell thought that was a good idea? The majority of the items in the season passes are recycled assets or recycled ideas in some way shape or form which makes it seem like they're not even worth the grind. And it is a grind because you get so little XP for game wins. It's really not even worth your time unless you're actively working on the season pass challenges for the XP boosts.

The most egregious change imo was the shifting of the MMR player rating tiers. Grand Champ used to be the highest rank. Then they finally added Supersonic Legend above Grand Champ along with Grand Champ 1, Grand Champ 2, and Grand Champ 3, and they shifted all the other tiers down in MMR to "balance the tiers." This blended Champ 1, Champ 2, and Champ 3 with Grand Champs so now most of the lobbies I play in have Grand Champs and the games become total sweat fests even in casual including triple WHAT A SAVE spams in quick chat.

This used to be my favorite game as you can probably tell from my close to 4000 hours logged. Unfortunately, it's just gotten incredibly stale and the MMR change, the lazy season passes, and lazy devs have turned what used to be my favorite game into something that I only hop into on rare occasions when I get the itch and have forgotten how stay it is.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Rocket League is less of a "sports game" and more of an actual sport. In FIFA or Madden you have a "pass" button, but to make a pass in Rocket League you have to drive your car into the ball at the right speed and angle to send it over to where your teammate is going. You have to create the pass yourself, and it can be anything, from a hard bounce off the back wall to a soft lob over the defender.

Passing, shooting, dribbling, tackles, jukes, they're all in the game, but you have to make them happen yourself, not just press the right button. At first, just driving car to ball is a challenge, but as your skill grows, the freedom to create any play you can imagine and execute is unlike anything you'll find in a "sports game". Together with the mechanical skill to do what you want with the ball, you'll have to develop positional awareness and learn proper rotation and game sense.

There are very few games that are consistently rewarding for hundreds or thousands of hours, that can keep challenging you as you improve, and improve, and improve beyond what you ever imagined you'd be capable of. In fact, this is the ONLY one I know.

Take this recommendation with a grain of salt as I am incredibly biased towards this game. Rocket League is a magnificent game where the ceiling of improvement feels almost infinite. There is always things you can work on and improve on. They can be flashy mechanics that after set-up are almost invincible or an incredibly consistent play style that punishes even the smallest of mistakes. I played the game up to Diamond 3 as just a game for fun and improvement, it gave months worth of entertaining content made possible by friends I met in match. For those on who like the more competitive side of games, unsurprisingly rocket league has competitive game modes with their own ranking systems. As of right now, I play in tournaments that are held by a third party outside of rocket league (that said I just want to briefly warn a few people that there are tournament scams in which someone asks you to join them in a tournament and use the information you type in to take your steam account). As for some downsides, skills gained in Rocket League don't transfer that great into other games. The other downside is solo-queuing can be frustrating with not knowing if your tm8 is toxic or at your level. Meeting someone in match that you like is a great way to avoid this. Most of the people I still play with today are people I met back in Diamond (or people they were already playing with). To sum all this up, Rocket League is a great game that rewards the time you spend on it. I highly recommend giving it a try and finding some people that are a similar skill level as you to play with and improve with!

It feels kinda silly to review this game on Steam since it's no longer available on this platform, but if you just want to know about the game in general, I definitely recommend it for a fun (though often frustrating) time.

The game's main modes are exactly what they look like, car soccer. It sounds simple, but getting good at the game's mechanics can take many hours just to feel okay with. Mastering stuff like being able to do aerials requires dedication.

But even if you're a more casual player, Rocket League is still a good time with friends or with just random players from the game's very active online scene. If you care about stuff like rankings, you'll be annoyed a lot having to deal with losses that aren't your fault and teammates who just don't gel with you. It's best not to take the game too seriously to avoid the aggravation.

It also has a lot of fun alternate modes, like being able to change the size or physics of the ball, doing basketball or ice hockey modes, and various limited time modes that will pop up like a football themed mode. Rocket League is a fun way to get in a quick gaming session if you only have like 10 or 15 minutes to kill, but it can also be nice to put a couple hours into for the night if you want to do something like a tournament.
